  • Meanwhile, the extension of ACA subsidies from the Obama era was pushed to mid-December for another vote

These fiscal tussles both affect the FY2026 deficit and Treasury issuance cadence, and add political pressure on the Fed.

II. Monetary Policy: Fed + BOJ

Section titled “II. Monetary Policy: Fed + BOJ”

1. Fed: From “hike + shrink” to “cut + end shrink”

Section titled “1. Fed: From “hike + shrink” to “cut + end shrink””

At the October meeting, the Fed already:

  • Lowered the fed funds rate 25 bp to 3.75%–4.00%
  • Announced QT2 would stop as of December 1, halting further balance-sheet runoff

Put simply: “rates move down, balance sheet stops declining”—policy shifts from tight to “mildly loose.”

But internally there is no unanimity; the October minutes showed clear divisions over further cuts, and Powell stressed that “whether to cut again in December is not a done deal.”

What to watch at the December 9–10 meeting?

  • Whether the dot plot and forward guidance spell out how many more cuts in 2026
  • Whether the language is “cut once, then observe” or signals entry into a sustained cutting cycle
  • How they assess the impact of the shutdown data gap (many official October data points were missing)

Markets have already priced in “one more cut in December”—banks from JP Morgan to BofA are betting on it.

If the outcome is “hold” or a more hawkish message, it would be a notable hit to high-valuation names, especially high-beta AI stocks.

2. Fed Personnel: Who succeeds Powell?

Section titled “2. Fed Personnel: Who succeeds Powell?”

Powell’s term expires May 2026. Trump has said multiple times, “I know who to pick,” but won’t replace him early.

Current storyline:

  • Treasury Secretary Bessent is leading the search, narrowing the list to five
  • Kevin Hassett, White House economic adviser, is the clear frontrunner in reports and betting markets
  • Bessent has hinted the name may drop before Christmas

Market takeaway is simple:

If the pick is more “political and openly pro-rapid cuts,” the Fed’s perceived independence post-2026 would be discounted, adding risk premia to the dollar and long-term inflation expectations.

In other words, this is not about a few days of trading; it sets the rules for the coming years.

3. BOJ: Yen hikes as an “invisible kill shot” to US stocks

Section titled “3. BOJ: Yen hikes as an “invisible kill shot” to US stocks”

On December 1, Ueda delivered a rare hawkish signal in Nagoya:

  • Explicitly said a hike will be discussed at the December meeting
  • Stressed that once the rate is raised to 0.75%, the path will be detailed
  • Also noted that even with a hike, Japan’s overall financial stance remains accommodative

Markets reacted immediately:

  • Yen strengthened quickly against the dollar
  • Japanese short-end yields hit multi-year highs
  • Global bond yields rose in tandem; US stocks pulled back that day

Why does this matter for US equity investors?

  • In recent years, plenty of global capital used cheap yen carry: borrow yen → buy Treasuries, buy US stocks, especially high-valuation tech
  • If yen rates keep rising and the currency stabilizes or rebounds, that “cheap money” pipeline gradually tightens
  • For growth stocks hypersensitive to rates and reliant on valuation expansion (AI names especially), this is a structural headwind

III. Data: Cooling Jobs + Easing Inflation

Section titled “III. Data: Cooling Jobs + Easing Inflation”

The prevailing market narrative is: “Slowing growth + weaker jobs + easing inflation → the Fed can safely cut more.”

We need to stay sober about the data itself.

1. Jobs: Official data catching up to reality

Section titled “1. Jobs: Official data catching up to reality”
  • Private datasets have for months flagged rising layoffs, more WARN notices, and tougher job searches
  • Consumer confidence slumped sharply in November, with the shutdown seen as a key drag
  • But because October data was halted by the shutdown, official Labor Department/BLS releases are only now getting back on track

December 16 (November nonfarm) and January 9 (December nonfarm):

If nonfarm adds and wage growth weaken noticeably:

  • Markets will feel firmer about “another 2–3 cuts in 2026”
  • Bullish for long-end Treasury yields, short-term positive for growth/tech

If the data stay firm:

  • It will deepen FOMC divisions over further cuts
  • Bearish for assets already priced for a dovish path (high-leverage REITs, high-valuation tech)

2. Inflation: November CPI is the “first real test” post-shutdown

Section titled “2. Inflation: November CPI is the “first real test” post-shutdown”

Because of the shutdown, October CPI was delayed; November CPI was pushed to December 18.

This CPI print matters for two reasons:

  • It’s the first full inflation read after the government reopened
  • Awkward timing—after the December 10 FOMC—meaning the Fed meets with an “incomplete” dataset

Markets expect November CPI YoY around 2.9%, with core a bit higher but still in a “near-target” range.

If November and December CPI both land in the 2%–3% band, the Fed will have stronger “political + data” cover to keep cutting slowly in 2026.

IV. AI Track: Two Scorecards from Broadcom & Micron

Section titled “IV. AI Track: Two Scorecards from Broadcom & Micron”

Over the past year, a handful of AI leaders captured most of the market’s gains. Year to date 2025, Alphabet and NVIDIA alone contributed roughly one-third of the S&P 500’s rise.

The violent swings in November largely asked: “Can AI investment returns justify current prices?”

In that context, the two December earnings reports are especially critical:

1. After hours December 11: Broadcom (AVGO)

Section titled “1. After hours December 11: Broadcom (AVGO)”

Watch three areas:

AI revenue mix and growth

  • Goldman and other banks expect Broadcom to raise FY2026 AI revenue guidance again
  • Some forecasts see YoY growth potentially topping 100%

Capex cadence of major customers (hyperscalers/lab clients)

  • Alphabet’s self-developed TPU is deeply tied to Broadcom’s manufacturing and ecosystem
  • If clients slow AI capex, Broadcom can’t escape the impact

Whether traditional businesses (handsets, broadband, enterprise networking) are being crowded out by AI

  • If legacy lines are pressured while AI surges, markets may treat Broadcom as “pure AI beta”
  • The opposite would frame it more as a “defensive AI beneficiary”

2. After hours December 17: Micron (MU)

Section titled “2. After hours December 17: Micron (MU)”

Micron is the temperature gauge on memory + HBM supply:

  • Pricing and production for HBM and high-end DRAM map directly to real AI server demand
  • If guidance shows data center demand still strong while PC/handset inventories clear, the story that “AI is pulling up the entire semi cycle” holds better
  • Conversely, if management stresses customers trimming inventory and pulling less than expected, markets would cut 2026 AI capex forecasts a second time

V. Fiscal & Politics: The Shutdown Was Just a Trailer

Section titled “V. Fiscal & Politics: The Shutdown Was Just a Trailer”

From October 1 to November 12, 2025, the US endured one of its longest shutdowns—40+ days:

  • The Census Bureau and BLS paused many data releases
  • Consumer confidence dropped sharply; retail sales weakened visibly
  • The White House economic team estimated direct costs of roughly $15 billion per week

The mid-November continuing resolution merely kicked the can to January 30, 2026:

  • Before then, Congress must agree on a full FY2026 budget and healthcare subsidy issues
  • Otherwise, either another shutdown or more short-term CRs

For markets, this means:

Uncertain Treasury supply + large deficit

  • Keeps upward pressure on long-end Treasury yields

Higher political risk premia

  • Especially if the next Fed Chair pick is clearly “aligned with White House wishes”
  • Layer on large tax cuts or new spending and markets will reprice the landscape

VI. “Santa Claus Rally”: Does It Still Work This Year?

Section titled “VI. “Santa Claus Rally”: Does It Still Work This Year?”

Wall Street calls the tendency for US stocks to rise during the last five trading days of the year plus the first two of the new year these seven days the “Santa Claus rally.”

Historical stats:

  • Since 1950, the S&P 500 has averaged ~1.3% gain over those seven days
  • Win rate close to 80%

Two caveats:

This is just a statistical pattern, not a law; 2024–2025 even saw a “reverse Santa Claus rally.”

This year is unusual:

  • AI bubble debate is fierce
  • The Fed just ended QT
  • Japan may hike; the US is debating how many more cuts

A more realistic view:

If we still get a small Santa-plus-New-Year bounce, treat it as “a sentiment reset thanks to rate-cut expectations and easier liquidity.”

But it cannot hide longer-term questions:

  • Whether AI valuations are reasonable
  • Whether jobs are clearly weakening
  • Whether fiscal policy is sustainable

VII. How Can Individual Investors Use This “Event Calendar”?

Section titled “VII. How Can Individual Investors Use This “Event Calendar”?”

Here is a practical playbook:

1. Bake the dates into your position rules

Section titled “1. Bake the dates into your position rules”

Around December 9–10 FOMC

  • Dial back high-leverage, short-term, all-in options bets
  • Keep the portfolio positioned to absorb two-way swings on meeting night

December 11–18 (AVGO / MU earnings + nonfarm + CPI)

  • Differentiate pure AI beta (all story, little cash flow) from companies with solid profits
  • Consider using indices/ETFs to hedge some single-stock risk

Late December–mid-January (Santa rally + new nonfarm/CPI round)

  • If the market surges over the holidays, trim overall portfolio valuation (e.g., shift from 100% tech to 60% tech + 40% defensive/value)
  • If the Santa rally is absent or even plunges, treat it seriously as an early warning for 2026 risk assets

2. Watch rates, not just the index

Section titled “2. Watch rates, not just the index”

During this stretch, moves in the Treasury curve matter more than index levels:

  • Short end (2-year) → captures expectations for the next 1–2 years of cuts
  • Long end (10-year) → reflects worries about long-term inflation + fiscal sustainability

If post-December we see “short end dives, long end rises,” that looks more like a “recession worry + fiscal risk” combo, not a clean equity-friendly rate-cut cycle.

3. Break the “story” into “cash flows + discount rate”

Section titled “3. Break the “story” into “cash flows + discount rate””

Over the next month-plus, we’re watching three dramas at once:

  • Fed: the discount-rate script
  • AI bellwether earnings: the cash-flow script
  • Fiscal and politics: the risk-premium script

Only when these three roughly line up can a “Santa Claus rally” morph into “the start of a truly sustainable bull market.”

item.title: No PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)
item.content:encoded:
No PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)

Section titled “No PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)”

For those following the US stock market, every month is packed with macro data, earnings calendars, and major events. Typically, we have to gather information from various websites and then painstakingly layout a “one-sheet summary”.

Previously, creating such charts required mastery of Photoshop or Canva. But now, with Gemini 3, you only need one reference image and a pile of messy text to generate a professional-grade financial calendar in minutes.

Today, I’ll walk you through how I used Gemini 3 to create a “December US Stock Financial Events Calendar”. The process was incredibly smooth, and the local editing capability in the final step truly amazed me! 👇

Step 1: Prepare Materials to “Feed” the AI

Section titled “Step 1: Prepare Materials to “Feed” the AI”

You can’t make bricks without straw. We need to prepare two things:

  1. Reference Style Image: Find an old calendar image with a layout you like. (I found a financial calendar; I liked its color scheme and timeline layout).

  1. Text Information: Compile important US stock events for December and January (such as Non-Farm Payrolls, Powell’s speeches, Broadcom earnings, Christmas rally, etc.) into text to send to the AI.

💡 The key here is: You don’t need to format the text; it can even be messy news excerpts. The AI will extract the key points itself.

Step 2: Let Gemini “Copycat”

Section titled “Step 2: Let Gemini “Copycat””

Open Gemini 3, upload the reference image from earlier, and enter the Prompt:

Prompt: “Referencing the calendar style in the screenshot, generate a calendar of important time points for US stocks in December and January based on the following content.” (Attach the compiled text content…)

Gemini responded very quickly. It rapidly identified the visual structure (Layout) of the reference image—dates on the left, icons in the middle, text on the right, and the color style at the bottom.

Generated Result (First Version): AI perfectly replicated the timeline style, and the icons were matched accurately (e.g., chip icons for chip earnings, a Christmas tree for Christmas).

⚠️ However, a small flaw appeared: The AI was too “faithful” to the original image and actually drew the Logo ID (watermark) from the reference image in the top left corner. This is obviously not what we wanted.

Step 3: God-tier Operation — Natural Language “Retouching”

Section titled “Step 3: God-tier Operation — Natural Language “Retouching””

Previously, in this situation, we would have to download the image, open PS, use the spot healing brush to remove it, and then add our own Logo.

But now, you just need to say one sentence to Gemini.

I hope to replace the Logo in the top left with my own brand “Vibe Sparking”.

My Modification Instruction: “Top left corner, below ‘One Sheet Summary’, left of ‘Rate Cut Expectations Rising’, inside the box, please change to Vibe Sparking. Keep other areas unchanged.”

This tests two of the AI’s capabilities:

  1. Spatial Localization: Understanding directional terms like “below top left corner, left of”.
  2. Inpainting/Local Editing: Changing only the specified area without destroying pixels in other parts of the image.

Step 4: The Moment of Miracle

Section titled “Step 4: The Moment of Miracle”

Gemini 3 quickly provided the second version feedback.

✨ Final Result: Look at the image below. The area that originally copied the Logo has been perfectly replaced with “Vibe Sparking”. The font style and background color blocks blend perfectly with the overall image, with no sense of violation. Meanwhile, the rest of the calendar (dates, icons, text) remained 100% consistent without any distortion.

📝 Summary and Thoughts

Section titled “📝 Summary and Thoughts”

Through this test, Gemini 3 demonstrated three powerful core capabilities:

  1. Style Transfer: Accurately understanding the color scheme, layout, and design logic of the reference image.
  2. Info Viz (Information Visualization): Transforming unstructured long text into clear, structured charts.
  3. Multimodal Editing: This surprised me the most. It’s not just “generating”, but “editing”. Change where you point, greatly lowering the barrier for ordinary people to create professional charts.

In the future, for event posters, schedules, or even long meeting minutes, as long as you have a good-looking “sample image”, you are a professional designer!

item.title: AI US Stock Market November Key Events Investment Research Report
item.content:encoded:
I. Overview of Core Events and Market Impact

Section titled “I. Overview of Core Events and Market Impact”

In November 2025, the US stock market faces a complex situation interwoven with five major categories of critical events, which will profoundly impact market direction. Based on current data analysis, the market is in a delicate balance of high valuations, low volatility, and high uncertainty.

  • The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling (November 5) is the biggest uncertainty factor this month. The Federal Court of Appeals has ruled that tariffs (reciprocal tariffs and fentanyl tariffs) implemented by Trump based on the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) were illegal. The Supreme Court will hold oral arguments on November 5, with a final ruling expected in late 2025 or early 2026. This ruling involves a risk of nearly $200 billion in tariff refunds. If the Supreme Court overturns the tariffs, the market may see significant positive news; if it supports the government, it implies continued trade uncertainty.
  • Sino-US trade relations saw a brief détente at the end of October. After meeting in Korea, a one-year truce agreement was reached: the US will reduce tariffs on Chinese goods from 57% to 47% (fentanyl-related tariffs from 20% to 10%), and China will suspend rare earth export restrictions for one year. However, this is merely a tactical truce, not a structural solution. Both sides retain the option to restart the trade war, and the risk of escalation in November should be watched.
  • The government shutdown has lasted 29 days (as of October 31), making it one of the longest in US history. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the shutdown will result in $7-14 billion in permanent GDP loss. The suspension of key economic data releases creates a “data black hole,” forcing the Federal Reserve to formulate policy without core data on employment, inflation, etc. Approximately 750,000 federal employees have been furloughed, and SNAP (food stamp) benefits will cease on November 1, further impacting consumer demand.

item.title: Tech Giants’ Q3 Earnings and Investment Playbook: AI‑Driven Opportunities and Risks
item.content:encoded:
In Q3 2025, U.S. tech giants delivered a mixed set of results. While the industry continues to benefit from the AI wave, performance diverged meaningfully. Google posted a historic milestone, surpassing $100B in quarterly revenue for the first time; Microsoft kept steady momentum with strong cloud and AI traction; Meta, meanwhile, was hit by a one‑time $16B deferred‑tax charge under a new U.S. tax law, triggering a 9% share‑price drop. In this market setup, investors need to capture opportunities precisely while balancing risk.

Q3 Earnings Snapshot: Divergence in the AI Era

Section titled “Q3 Earnings Snapshot: Divergence in the AI Era”

Google: A Historic Breakthrough with Across‑the‑Board Beats

Section titled “Google: A Historic Breakthrough with Across‑the‑Board Beats”

Alphabet set a new record in Q3, crossing the $100B mark for the first time with $102.3B in revenue, up 16% y/y and well above the $99.85B consensus. EPS reached $2.87, up 35% y/y.

The standout was Google Cloud: revenue hit $15.16B, up 34% y/y and above the $14.72B street view. Backlog surged to $155B, reflecting strong enterprise demand for AI infrastructure. Search and Other posted $56.57B, up 14.5% y/y, underscoring that the core search franchise remains healthy even amid competition from AI assistants like ChatGPT.

Shares rose more than 6% after hours, as the market grew more confident in Google’s AI transition and cloud‑business acceleration. Management raised full‑year capex guidance to $91–93B, signaling continued investment in AI infrastructure.

Meta: Strong Operations, Accounting Shock

Section titled “Meta: Strong Operations, Accounting Shock”

Meta reported Q3 revenue of $51.524B, up 26% y/y and above expectations. But a “tax storm” flipped sentiment.

Under the newly enacted U.S. tax bill (“One Big Beautiful Bill”), companies must recognize accumulated deferred‑tax assets in a one‑time reassessment. Because Meta holds substantial deferred‑tax assets and has heavy U.S.‑domiciled equity, it recognized a one‑off deferred‑tax expense of roughly $16B, driving an 83% y/y plunge in net income; EPS came in at $1.05, far below expectations.

Ex‑tax effects, Meta’s ad and Reels businesses remained strong. AI‑driven ad targeting and performance continued improving, with sales growth at 23% — outpacing Google’s 13% — highlighting Meta’s lead in AI‑powered ad tech.

Management guided 2025 capex at $70–72B, with another major step‑up in 2026. The aggressive investment plan shows Meta is spending heavily in the “race to AGI,” but it also raises near‑term margin and cash‑flow concerns.

Shares fell 9%, reflecting market pessimism around the one‑off tax expense and elevated forward spending.

Microsoft: Steady Growth with AI Dividends Materializing

Section titled “Microsoft: Steady Growth with AI Dividends Materializing”

Microsoft posted Q3 revenue of $77.67B, up 18.4% y/y and above the $75.49B consensus. EPS was $3.72 vs. $3.66 expected.

Intelligent Cloud revenue reached $30.31B, up 18%+ y/y, with strong AI workload demand continuing to power Azure. Business Software delivered $33.02B, up 15%+ y/y, with sustained growth in Microsoft 365 business subscriptions — clear evidence of successful GenAI integration.

Free‑cash‑flow margin hit 33%, up sharply from 29.4% a year ago, indicating Microsoft is scaling while controlling costs and preserving cash‑generation strength.

Valuation Benchmarks: Finding a Margin of Safety

Section titled “Valuation Benchmarks: Finding a Margin of Safety”

Valuations vary widely. Google screens as most attractive with PEG 1.88 and P/S 8.95, paired with a solid 5‑year forward EPS CAGR estimate of 15.61%. Meta’s PEG is 2.17 — slightly above Google’s — but its faster sales growth (23%) and 5‑year EPS CAGR of 12.54% point to better growth optionality.

Microsoft’s setup is comparatively steady (P/E 39.70, PEG 2.35). While not as inexpensive as Google, its 16.86% forward growth outlook and 33% FCF margin reflect a superior business model.

Risk flags are clearer for NVDA and TSLA. NVDA trades at P/E 58.93 and P/S 88.59; despite a 5‑year growth rate of 91.83%, current multiples already discount very high growth — arguably to excess. TSLA’s P/E of 308x is even more stretched while profits are falling this quarter — the valuation is not supported by fundamentals here.

Why Meta’s Valuation Took a Hit While Google Outperformed

Section titled “Why Meta’s Valuation Took a Hit While Google Outperformed”

Meta’s $16B tax expense does not indicate fundamental deterioration; it stems from a one‑time accounting change. The new U.S. tax bill requires a comprehensive reassessment of accumulated deferred‑tax assets. Meta was hit hard because of concentrated U.S. equity exposure, the abrupt implementation of the policy, and prior tax strategies being re‑evaluated under the new rules.

By contrast, Google and Microsoft have more diversified deferred‑tax asset structures, with a higher share of overseas equity, hence less impact from the change.

Investment Scenarios

Section titled “Investment Scenarios”

Option 1: Balanced Growth + Safety Margin (★★★★★)

Section titled “Option 1: Balanced Growth + Safety Margin (★★★★★)”

Allocate Google 60% + Microsoft 40%. Google’s PEG is the lowest (1.88), Cloud growth is the fastest (34%), and market expectations remain conservative. Microsoft’s stability and cash‑flow strength are exemplary. This blend offers growth with a margin of safety — suitable for conservative, longer‑term investors seeking stable returns.

Option 2: Growth Seekers with Moderate Risk (★★★★)

Section titled “Option 2: Growth Seekers with Moderate Risk (★★★★)”

Allocate Meta 50% + Google 50%. Meta’s share‑price drop offers an entry opportunity; ex the one‑time tax, core operations remain strong. Meta’s AI‑driven ad engine and 23% sales growth outpace Google’s 13%, offering higher growth potential. If Meta’s AI investments start to pay off in 2026, shares could rebound 15–25%.

Option 3: Aggressive Growth with Higher Risk (★★)

Section titled “Option 3: Aggressive Growth with Higher Risk (★★)”

Allocate Meta 40% + Amazon 40% + Google 20%. Await Amazon’s Q3 print; rebalance if it beats. AWS and Advertising both appear to be re‑accelerating, with a 5‑year EPS CAGR estimate of 19.22%. This configuration leans on Amazon beating expectations; if results disappoint, adjust quickly.

Option 4: Absolute Avoid

Section titled “Option 4: Absolute Avoid”

Avoid NVDA, TSLA, and AAPL for now. NVDA’s 58.93x P/E and 88.59x P/S are at historical highs; any growth deceleration can trigger valuation compression. TSLA’s 308x P/E with sharply falling profit is a severe mismatch between valuation and fundamentals. AAPL’s P/E ~41 and PEG 4.27 imply the weakest valuation‑to‑growth pairing among the group.

Conclusion and Recommendations

Section titled “Conclusion and Recommendations”

Google, powered by Cloud acceleration and a comparatively restrained valuation, screens as the safest choice. Meta is building a long‑term moat via aggressive AI investment and ad‑tech innovation; the current sell‑off creates opportunity. Microsoft remains the steady compounder — a dual winner in cloud and AI.

Suggested portfolio weighting for most investors:

  • Google: 45%
  • Meta: 30%
  • Microsoft: 25%

This mix targets an 8–15% annualized return over the next 12 months while keeping volatility in a 15–20% band.

Note: This report is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; invest prudently.

item.title: From Exploration to Fix: How Claude Code Thinks and Reasons Through a SQLAlchemy Transaction Rollback Issue
item.content:encoded:
This technical blog is distilled from a real production incident investigation. It focuses on how Claude Code “explores → thinks → reasons” to quickly pinpoint the root cause, ship the smallest viable fix, and propose follow‑up structural improvements.

The problem occurred in the mailflow service in production. The core error was:

From the surrounding logs, the failure happened when executing an INSERT into the emails table. Subsequent database operations then entered a “cascade failure” state.

1. Context and Goals

Section titled “1. Context and Goals”
  • Context: While handling inbound emails (parsing, creating records, forwarding, moving IMAP folders), mailflow occasionally fails the entire processing chain.
  • Goals:
    • Identify the primary trigger of the transaction failure;
    • Explain why all subsequent DB operations report the same error;
    • Restore processing with the smallest, lowest‑risk change;
    • Provide structural improvement suggestions to increase robustness.

2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidence

Section titled “2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidence”

Leveraging Claude Code’s code search and cross‑context capabilities, we proceeded “from symptoms to root cause” in order:

  • Locking onto logs and trigger point

    • The logs show the exception stems from the SQLAlchemy Session state: after a prior transaction failure, rollback() was not performed, leaving the current Session invalid.

  • Locating key code paths

    • mailflow/app/db.py: connection and session factory definitions.
    • mailflow/app/mail.py: main business flow, record creation, and commit points.
    • mailflow/app/utils.py: logging and WeCom notification entry notify_and_log.

  • Evidence 1: Module‑level global Session

    • At the top of mail.py there is:
    • Once any flush/commit fails, this global Session becomes invalid, and all subsequent DB operations that rely on it will fail until an explicit session.rollback() is issued.

  • Evidence 2: Missing exception handling and rollback

    • Multiple session.commit() calls lack try/except/rollback protection:
      • Creating the mail record (create_mail)
      • Relating attachments to mail (_relation_attachment_and_mail)
      • Updating status when dealing with request results (deal_requests_result)
      • Large sections of the main flow in process_mail

Conclusion: The first failed DB operation puts the global Session into an invalid state. Because rollback() is missing, all later commits and even queries on that path fail with the same error, forming a “cascade failure”.

3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verification

Section titled “3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verification”

  1. Hypothesis: An INSERT/UPDATE exception (possibly from data constraints, transient network issues, or the pool) invalidates the global Session; without rollback(), subsequent steps (status updates, attachment relations, mail moves) all fail.

  2. Code verification:

    • Found the global session = session_factory();
    • Searched for session.commit() call sites — most lack except: session.rollback();
    • This matches the error semantics exactly.

  3. Strategy: Move fast with minimal change to restore stability first, then evaluate structural refactoring.

4. Fix Strategy and Implementation

Section titled “4. Fix Strategy and Implementation”

We prioritized the fix in three levels (P0 → P2):

  • P0 (immediate, smallest change): add session.rollback() in exception handlers so the Session can self‑recover.
  • P1 (comprehensive guard): wrap every commit() with try/except/rollback to avoid any single failure taking down the rest of the flow.
  • P2 (structural): replace the module‑level global Session with scoped_session to isolate session state across processing flows (recommended, not mandatory for the hotfix).

4.1 Key Patch Snippets

Section titled “4.1 Key Patch Snippets”
  • Add rollback in the main flow (mailflow/app/mail.py)
  • Guard status updates when handling request results (wrap both success and failure branches)
  • Guard establishing mail–attachment relations
  • Add protection for creating the mail record create_mail

4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)

Section titled “4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)”

Eliminate the risk where a “global Session drags down all flows” by using scoped_session:

Note: scoped_session provides better isolation in concurrent/multithreaded environments and reduces cross‑request contamination. The production hotfix first ensures rollback semantics are correct and complete; then evaluate the migration cost/benefit.

5. Validation and Regression

Section titled “5. Validation and Regression”

Suggested validation steps:

  • Single reproducible mail replay: replay a previously failing mail and observe whether the chain recovers;
  • Observe logs: the message “Can’t reconnect until invalid transaction is rolled back” should no longer appear;
  • Manual spot‑check: verify IMAP folder moves, forwarding, and database state;
  • Controlled load: increase the number of sample mails to ensure multiple commit points correctly roll back and continue.

6. Lessons Learned and Best Practices

Section titled “6. Lessons Learned and Best Practices”
  • Anti‑pattern: a module‑level global Session, once invalid, causes chain‑wide cascade failures.
  • Principle: every commit() should be wrapped by try/except + rollback; also rollback() in the top‑level exception handler of the main flow.
  • Design: adopt a failure‑resilient session model (scoped_session or acquire/release per processing unit).
  • Operations: log and alert immediately (this project uses WeCom via notify_and_log), and include key identifiers (uid, subject, time, to_list) in the message.

7. Claude Code’s Methodology

Section titled “7. Claude Code’s Methodology”

This “explore → reason → fix” path generalizes to most code‑level issues:

  1. Quickly bound the problem: start from the error semantics and match the most likely layer (transaction/session management).
  2. Evidence‑driven search: find the relevant files, variables, and functions (session_factory, commit() call sites).
  3. Hypothesize → falsify/corroborate: propose “global Session + no rollback → cascade failure”, then find direct evidence in code.
  4. Smallest change first: add rollback() so the Session can recover and stop the bleeding.
  5. Structural improvement: propose scoped_session as the follow‑up path, balancing benefit and migration cost.

This assessment of Intel’s current state touches the core elements of its transformation. Based on the latest Q3 2025 results and market developments, we validate and enrich the thesis with a comprehensive analysis.

CEO Performance: A Threefold Test of EQ, IQ, and Financial Acumen

Lip-Bu Tan’s outstanding record does support the “top-tier CEO” conclusion:

IQ Dimension

  • Holds a B.Sc. in Physics from Nanyang Technological University, an M.S. in Nuclear Engineering from MIT, and an MBA from the University of San Francisco; deep technical grounding

EQ Dimension

  • Widely regarded as a customer‑oriented leader. Shortly after taking office, he visited 22 prospective customers and partners, demonstrating exceptional relationship‑building
  • His network across the semiconductor ecosystem is “second to none”, enabling swift strategic investments from Nvidia and SoftBank
  • McKinsey describes his leadership style as “radical transparency”, which is crucial for building trust with the board and management

Financial Acumen

“Securing backing from competitors like Nvidia and SoftBank” is indeed the best demonstration of financial acumen. In August 2025 he brought in:

  • US Government: $8.9B investment (≈10% stake) at $20.47/share
  • SoftBank: $2.0B investment (at $23/share)
  • Nvidia: $5.0B investment (at $23.28/share, ≈4% stake)

These deals not only eased Intel’s funding pressure but, more importantly, provided strategic validation. As of after-hours on October 24, the US Government’s position had returned 102.1% (from $20.47 to $41.37)—a “double in two months”, fully consistent with the observation.

Section titled “Strategy: Core Logic of Localizing AI Compute”

18A Process Progress

Section titled “18A Process Progress”

Intel 18A began volume production in the second half of 2025, ahead of TSMC’s N2 node by weeks to months. The process adopts two breakthrough technologies—RibbonFET (GAA transistors) and PowerVia (backside power delivery). Versus Intel 3:

Microsoft Order Confirmed

Other Customers

AI PC Demand

Q3 results show Client Computing Group (CCG) revenue of $5.0B, up 7% year over year. Intel estimates 2025 PC TAM at 290 million units, with strong AI‑driven demand.

Valuation: Validating Price Targets

Based on the latest data, we quantitatively validate the valuation framework:

$40 Price Target Validation

Section titled “$40 Price Target Validation”

“A $40 share price already embeds 20% revenue growth over the next two years; gross margin stable at 40%; and delivery on AI PC and the 18A process.” Calculations show:

  • At $40, EV/Sales is ~3.8x
  • If 2025 revenue is $54B and grows at a 20% CAGR for the next two years, 2027 would reach ~$78B
  • This level broadly reflects the base case, but upside appears limited (~4.8%)

$50 Price Target (Further Re‑rating)

Section titled “$50 Price Target (Further Re‑rating)”

“Requires Intel Foundry to secure large external customers.” Validation:

  • At $50, EV/Sales is ~4.8x
  • Upside: +31.0%
  • Catalysts: Microsoft Maia 2 successful volume ramp; AMD foundry cooperation; 18A yields at commercial standards; additional large external customer wins

This valuation requires Intel to demonstrate that its foundry business can compete with TSMC and that 18A achieves commercial success.

Key Risks to Monitor

Technology Execution Risk

Section titled “Technology Execution Risk”

Reports in August indicated yield challenges in key 18A manufacturing steps. Although subsequent results signal good progress, stability at volume production still needs to be proven.

See the official repo and docs for sources.

Why this is worth trying

Section titled “Why this is worth trying”
  • Not a chat box, but a CLI that “lands” work: one key to switch into Shell mode and run native commands; press again to return to the agent to explain logs, generate scripts, and complete parameters.
  • Works with Zsh: install the zsh plugin, hit Ctrl-K to toggle agent mode in the terminal—switching back and forth is smooth.
  • Speaks ACP (Agent Client Protocol): this means it can be used as an “external agent” inside editors like Zed. One protocol connects any editor with any agent—that’s where things are heading.
  • Supports MCP tools: load third‑party tools via MCP conventions, like snapping in browser debugging and context search like Lego bricks.

Shell/Agent mode toggle: press Ctrl-K. Shell mode runs commands directly; built‑in shell commands like cd aren’t supported yet.

Restart Zsh and use Ctrl-K to enter agent mode; press again to exit.

Then create a new thread in Zed’s Agent panel to use it.

item.title: Will Documentation-Driven AI Coding Become the New 'Spaghetti Mountain'? Pros and Cons of BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec
item.content:encoded:
Remember the days when “spaghetti code💩” used to give everyone a headache? With AI copilots like Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini in the mix, we have stumbled into a brand-new pitfall—the “documentation spaghetti💩.” Documentation-driven AI programming has become a hot trend: write a clear specification first, then let AI generate the code. It sounds wonderful—no more guessing what the model wants, just provide a well-written brief and code appears automatically. The truth, though, is that if you take the wrong approach, the documentation can pile up into a brand-new spaghetti mountain that leaves you laughing and crying at the same time 😅.

Introduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?

Section titled “Introduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?”

Let’s start with these documentation-driven AI programming tools that are making the rounds—they each have their own personality:

BMAD Method – a “big and comprehensive” framework whose full name is Breakthrough Method for Agile AI-Driven Development. Its ambitions are huge: it tries to simulate a complete agile squad with AI. There is an analyst AI, an architect AI, a developer AI, a tester AI—each playing a role so that planning, coding, and testing all get staged like a full production. BMAD ships with a CLI and a web UI, plus special “script files” and context management so the AI team can collaborate. It usually unfolds in two phases: first the “analyst/product manager/architect” agents do the planning and design, then the “Scrum Master/developer” agents write the actual code. The upside is a thorough workflow that stays orderly—ideal for large, complex projects that demand clear documentation and division of labor. The downside is that it is cumbersome to use, has a steep learning curve, and expects the underlying model to truly understand the documentation you write.

Spec-Kit – an open-source utility on GitHub that layers a bit of “process” on top of your existing AI coding assistant. Developers use the command line to nudge AI through a “Specification → Plan → Tasks → Implementation” four-step. In short, Spec-Kit asks you to nail the requirements first, then guides AI to break work down and produce code. It turns your specification markdown into an “executable document” using commands like /specify, /plan, and /tasks. It is lightweight and flexible, does not force you to revamp your workflow, and is model-agnostic. Great for solo builders or small teams that want to add structure and improve AI-generated code quality.

OpenSpec – a minimalist newcomer that believes “simple is better.” You write a slim Markdown spec and pair it with a handful of commands to finish the job. Its flow has only three steps: submit a change proposal, let AI produce the task list, then let AI apply the spec to modify the code. The highlight is efficiency: the specs stay lean, token usage stays low, and there is barely any metadata. It works well for individuals or small teams chasing extreme speed—minor tweaks get done in minutes. The trade-off is that model support is still limited, but it is so easy to learn that there is almost no overhead.

Spot the pattern? These tools share the same philosophy: document first, then drive the AI. The goal is to reduce the uncertainty of vibe coding by giving AI a clear rulebook so code quality becomes controllable. Ideal in theory—but reality bites. If you are not careful, the documentation you create can morph into another giant spaghetti pile. Why does that happen? Read on.

Four Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster

Section titled “Four Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster”

1. Lack of Structure

Section titled “1. Lack of Structure”

Code is constrained by syntax—one misplaced comma and it will not even run. Documentation is much freer, and AI is not human. When a model stares at free-form, meandering text, its comprehension goes sideways. Code is deterministic; specifications are often vague and open to interpretation. If your documentation is loosely structured, the AI sees the world through fogged glass, and it is no surprise when the code it generates veers off in the wrong direction.

2. Inconsistent AI Understanding

Section titled “2. Inconsistent AI Understanding”

Even if you write a decent document, there is no guarantee the AI will interpret it the same way every time. Seasoned developers know the saying “a thousand readers, a thousand Hamlets”—and AI thinks even more differently from humans. ChatGPT might implement the feature correctly today, but a different model tomorrow could distort your intent. Documentation lacks the compiler’s safety net, so misunderstandings can hide in plain sight and quietly plant landmines.

3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors

Section titled “3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors”

We all know large language models hallucinate—confidently fabricating details. When AI uses incomplete or ambiguous documentation to write code, the stakes rise. Miss a detail in your spec and the AI might “fill in the gaps” with something that looks plausible but is wrong. Worse still, if that flawed AI-generated documentation or code gets reused later, another AI might treat it as gospel truth. Errors balloon like rumors: once they make it into formal docs, people and models alike will keep getting misled.

4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves

Section titled “4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves”

Finally, consider the complexity of the tools. Adopting Spec-Kit or BMAD might require extra software and brand-new rituals. You can end up wrestling with tooling, pouring hours into crafting specs and calibrating workflows, while actual coding time shrinks. If you do not internalize the framework, you may copy templates mechanically, letting documentation drift away from the code. Like wielding a scalpel without training—the damage can be greater than doing nothing.

How to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools

Section titled “How to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools”

The pitfalls sound daunting, but do not lose heart. With a tiered usage strategy, documentation-driven programming can still pave a smoother road:

Use direct prompts for tiny tweaks

Section titled “Use direct prompts for tiny tweaks”

When you are only adjusting a small logic branch or styling tweak, there is no need to assemble a grand spec. In these cases, asking Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, or Cursor directly is fastest. Explain the request in a sentence or two and let the AI offer a diff or snippet. You save time and stay focused. As veterans like to say: small asks do not need the full ceremony; if a quick chat solves it, skip the paperwork.

Reach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes

Section titled “Reach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes”

If you are adding a mid-sized feature—multiple steps, not massive—consider a lightweight tool such as Spec-Kit or OpenSpec. Spend ten minutes drafting an MVP-level spec that captures key requirements and edge cases, then hand it to the AI to refine the plan and tasks. Spec-Kit decomposes work item by item; OpenSpec minimizes context switching and handles the change in a few commands. The key is to keep the spec concise, covering only what is necessary. Data shows that compact specs are easier for AI to execute faithfully and more efficient overall. Once the feature ships, remember to update canonical docs or clean up temporary specs to prevent outdated information from piling up.

Deploy BMAD for major overhauls

Section titled “Deploy BMAD for major overhauls”

For large-scale refactors or brand-new complex subsystems—the real “surgery”—you need a rigorous approach. This is where a multi-agent framework like BMAD earns its keep: it orchestrates end-to-end planning, architecture, and task allocation. Think of it as hiring a virtual AI team to keep big projects on the rails. Of course, humans must stay in the loop—never blindly accept each AI output; review and adjust. Before spinning up BMAD, weigh the costs: it takes time and demands strong model comprehension. That investment can pay off for long-lived initiatives, but the documentation it produces—specs, user stories, and more—should evolve with the code. Do not toss it aside after one run; maintain it alongside the project or you will be rebuilding from scratch next time.

No matter the scale, remember the “documentation MVP” principle: the doc should cover only what is necessary and true right now. Do not chase completeness for its own sake. Many veterans delete temporary specs once a feature is done because the code itself is already clear. Instead of hoarding outdated notes that mislead people, keep a lean, accurate reference and update it as the product evolves. Documentation earns its value by reflecting reality; once it drifts, it is just dead weight.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Documentation-driven programming is a double-edged sword in the AI era. Used well, it makes development more efficient and orderly; misused, it spawns fresh spaghetti mountains. Ambitious young engineers should absolutely explore new tools, but not worship them blindly. Whether we are talking code or docs, the heart of the matter is understanding the requirement and keeping information current. Whenever you decide to write a spec or pick a tool, ask yourself: “Is this making the problem clearer—or just adding complexity?”

Here’s to every developer mastering these AI tools, producing docs that stay crisp and useful, and turning documentation into an asset—not a burden. We all want higher productivity, not a literal spaghetti mountain blocking the office! 💩

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

When you build cross-platform BLE, iOS is always the pickier one. We were integrating with a blood glucose pump, and Android sailed through while iOS refused to respond. Even more interesting, two AI assistants—Codex and Claude Code—returned completely different answers. In the end, Codex hit the mark; Claude Code did not. This article reconstructs the entire process and talks about how “AI debugging styles” can differ.

When building cross-platform Bluetooth applications, the BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) stack on iOS often gives developers headaches. Recently our team faced a tricky iOS BLE connection problem, especially when connecting to a blood glucose pump. The interesting twist: two different AI assistants—Codex and Claude Code—produced entirely different solutions, and only Codex succeeded.

This article digs into the essence of the problem, contrasts the two lines of reasoning, and offers guidance for developers who run into similar issues.

  1. Second attempt: Noticed a 2-second delay before the “connection success” callback

Codex’s Diagnostic Steps

    • That causes the operations to fail
